title: Adaptation funding and vulnerability indexes.
sections:
Adaptation funding and vulnerability indexes.

The map shows the correlation between adaptation funding and vulnerability indexes on a scatter plot. It uses data from Climate Funds Update on four multilateral adaptation funds (Pilot Programme for Climate Reslience, the Least Developed Countries Fund, Adaptation Fund and Special Climate Change Fund), three vulnerability indexes (GAIN, Germanwatch and Dara) and the Human Development Index. The map is interactive to allow you to explore relationships between funds and indexes.

Figure 1. Scatter plot of funding levels and vulnerability ratings based on the GAIN index and four multilateral adaptation funds (GAIN, Germanwatch and Dara). Each plot represents a country, with the size representing the amount of funding received. The X Axis represents the level of vulnerability and the Y Axis represents the total amount of aid received.

How to read the map

Vulnerability is displayed on the x-axis and total funding in millions on the y-axis. The size of the point was used to represent the size of the funding relative to all other funding. The adaptation funds are coded in different colours for ease of understanding: PPCR in blue, LDC in yellow, AF in green and the SCCF in red. The adaptation funding per index diagrams could then be used to examine how funding was divided proportionally, and how and where each index allocated funding on the vulnerability scale.

The map shows how strongly each fund correlates with the various vulnerability indexes. If there is a strong correlation the countries will cluster in one corner or along a trend line. While there is no suggestion that these funds use these specific indices to assess vulnerability, it is interesting to examine the relationships between funds and indices.

How the map is built (map building protocol)

It was necessary to select the most prominent indices in order to gauge the location of countries on each vulnerability scale. The selected indices were Germanwatch’s Climate Risk Index (CRI), DARA’s Climate Vulnerability Monitor (CVM) and the Global Adaptation Initiative’s Global Adaptation Index (GAIN). In addition to these vulnerability indices, the United Nation’s Human Development Index (HDI) was also added upon the suggestion of subject matter expert, Matthew Mc Kinnon (United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and editor of DARA's Climate Vulnerability Monitor). In the case of adaptation funding, the HDI is particularly interesting as it is a more established index (developed by Pakistani economist Mahbub ul Haq in 1990) and might be considered less controversial than the vulnerability indices as a premise for adaptation funding. The HDI was also used to test our assumption that adaptation aid could correspond to development aid. Using the HDI in this way, we would expect to see a high correlation between the HDI and adaptation funding and vulnerability.

These indices concerning vulnerability (and development) could thus be correlated with the four multilateral adaptation funds, the Least Developed Countries Fund (LDCF), the Adaptation Fund (AF), the Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF) and Pilot Programme for Climate Resilience (PPCR). The index rankings were transformed into a consistent scale for comparability and the totals for multilateral funding for each country produced.
